docs.summary:
Radio button groups are used for selecting one of a number of
 options. Radio button groups consist of a list of [options](#Option). Each
 [option](#Option) contains a label, which is what the user sees, and a
 value, which is what is used in code and stored in you collections.
Sets or gets the options in a radio button group.
description: Setting the `options` property sets all the [options](#Option)
available to a user.
Set `options` to an empty array (`[]`) to remove the current radio button group options.
Getting the `options` property returns the current
list of [options](#Option) available to a user.
You cannot modify the data array in-place. To add, change, or remove
individual radio button options:
1. Store the value of the `options` property in a variable.
1. Make changes to the options array.
1. Reset the `options` property with the modified array.

examples.title: Get the list of options and the first option's label and value from a radio button group
Set the list of options for a radio button group
Add an option to a radio button group

extra.description:
This example retrieves the options of a radio button group, adds a new
 option, and then overwrites the old options.

docs.summary: Sets or gets the index of the selected option.
description: Setting the `selectedIndex` property sets the option at
that index to be the selected option. To set one of the options to be
selected, set the `selectedIndex` property to an index between `0` and
`options.length - 1`.
To reset the radio button group to have no option
selected, set the `selectedIndex` property to `undefined`.
Getting the `selectedIndex` property returns the index of
the currently selected option. If no value is selected, the
`selectedIndex` property returns `undefined`.

examples.title: Get the index of the selected option
Select the first option by index

docs.summary: Gets an object containing information about the radio button group's styles.
description: The following styles can be used with radio button groups:
+ [`backgroundColor`]($w.Style.html#backgroundColor)
+ [`borderColor`]($w.Style.html#borderColor)
+ [`borderWidth`]($w.Style.html#borderWidth)
+ [`color`]($w.Style.html#color)
Getting or setting a radio button group's styles, gets or sets the styles of the
radio button group's regular state. It does not set the styles of the radio button group's hover,
focus, error, or disabled states.

docs.summary: Sets or gets the value of the selected option.
description: Setting the `value` property sets the [`Option`](#Option)
with that value to be the selected option. You must set the `value`
property to a value that exists in the [`options`](#options) list.
To reset the radio button group to have no option
selected, set the `value` property to `null` or `undefined`.
Getting the `value` property returns the value of
the currently selected option. If no value is selected, the
`value` property returns an empty string.

examples.title: Get the value of the selected option

notes:
Changing a radio button group's `value` in code does not trigger an `onChange` event.

 If a radio button group is connected to a dataset, setting the radio button group's `value`
 in code does not set the value of the connected field in the dataset.
 That means if you use the dataset to perform a submit, the value changed
 in code is not reflected in the submitted item.

 To submit the new value using a dataset, set the field's value using the
 [`setFieldValue()`](wix-dataset.html#setFieldValue) function before
 performing the submit.

docs.summary: An object used by the `options` property that contains the attributes of a radio button item.

relatedContent.text: Setting Labels and Values for Radio Buttons and Dropdown Lists

FAQs.title: Should I use radio buttons or a dropdown for my input element?
FAQs.markdown:
Dropdowns and radio buttons provide the same basic functionality. Here are some tips on when to use one or the other:

**Dropdowns:**

*   When you have many choices. This prevents clutter on your page.
*   When the default option is recommended or likely to be chosen. Dropdowns emphasize the default option since it's the initial option visitors see.

**Radio Buttons:**

*   When you want your site visitors to read and compare all options. 
*   When you only have a few options. Visitors can quickly read the options and make their choice.
*   When time is crucial or the input form is long. Using dropdowns requires an extra click.

FAQs.title: What is the difference between the label and value of a radio button group option?
FAQs.markdown: Each [`Option`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/$w.RadioButtonGroup.html#Option) in a radio button group has a `label` and a `value`. The `label` is the text that visitors see, and the `value` is used in code and stored in your collections. [Learn more](https://support.wix.com/en/article/setting-labels-and-values-for-radio-buttons-and-dropdown-lists).

FAQs.title: How do I set a default selection for my radio button group? How do I remove a default selection?
FAQs.markdown: Use the [`selectedIndex`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/$w.RadioButtonGroup.html#selectedIndex) property to set a default selected option for your radio buttons. For no selected option, set the [`selectedIndex`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/$w.RadioButtonGroup.html#selectedIndex) property to `undefined`.
